While [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack") aims to keep most monsters, items, and rules identical with their counterparts in Vanilla NetHack, some changes have been made for purposes of balance, quality of life, and fun. This page does not list expansions to the game, such as new levels, monsters, or items. It only lists features which are different than their original incarnations.

## Quality-of-life changes

This section lists changes that were made for the purposes of quality of life, and where the changes originated.

### xNetHack

- Looking at monsters now tells you what weapon they are wielding, and whether they are armored. Farlooking at a monster provides you with a list of their resistances, attacks, and other statistics. The intention behind this page is to make looking at the wiki during play largely unnecessary.
- Paranoid trap and swimming confirmation.
- Carrying capacity and inventory slots are displayed for the player.
- Martial arts users never have clumsy kicks.
- All wands with unambiguous engraving messages auto-identify when engraved with.
- Blessed stethoscopes can identify eggs.

### L

- Colored walls and floors, using modified version of L's colored walls and floors patch.

### NAO

- The `hilite_hidden_stairs` option highlights stairs with objects on top of them. This is enabled by default.

### DynaHack

- Skill progress is visible to the player in the form of a percentage.

### Original

- **The [mysterious force](/wiki/Mysterious_force "Mysterious force") has been removed.**
- **The [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") can be started at level 10.**
- The [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor") blocks all forms of [teleportation](/wiki/Teleportation "Teleportation").
- Killing the [quest leader](/wiki/Quest_leader "Quest leader") will remove the mysterious force preventing access to the rest of the quest.
- Deadly [poison](/wiki/Poison "Poison") no longer instantly kills the player character, but instead causes both HP and attribute damage.
- \#give can be used to give items to the player's pet or [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") monsters, putting the items directly in their inventory. This streamlines the process of enticing pets to wield weapons or put on armor.
- [Artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish") is based on the number of artifacts wished for, not the number of artifacts generated, preventing the increased number of artifacts from making artifact wishing more difficult.

## Object changes

- [Pick-axes](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe") weigh less.
- [Robes](/wiki/Robe "Robe") are now referred to as mystic robes, and robe is a wishable category of item.
- Additional types of items can be poisoned.
- Warhammers deal 1d12 damage.
- The dungeon contains [furnaces](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace") in addition to the usual fountains and sinks.

## Monster changes

- Unique demons are more dangerous, as detailed on their own [subpage](/wiki/SpliceHack/Unique_demons "SpliceHack/Unique demons").
- [Tigers](/wiki/Tiger "Tiger") and [demonic monsters](/wiki/Demons "Demons") have had their colors changed in order to make room for new monsters.
- [Zruties](/wiki/Zruty "Zruty") have been moved to the [Y](/wiki/Apelike_creature "Apelike creature") monster class in order to allow for [zouthern animals](/wiki/Zouthern_animals "Zouthern animals").
- [Bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") files of players that were level 15 or above contain a [spectre](/wiki/Spectre "Spectre") instead of a ghost.
- The [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") has a weapon attack.
- [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu") wields a triple flail, giving him a much higher damage output.
- [Giants](/wiki/Giant "Giant") and [ogre kings](/wiki/Ogre_king "Ogre king") can rarely knock the player back with their attacks.
- Most [mummies](/wiki/Mummies "Mummies") can inflict the [withering](/wiki/Withering "Withering") status effect on enemies that they attack in melee.
- [Ice devils](/wiki/Ice_devils "Ice devils") can inflict [fumbling](/wiki/Fumbling "Fumbling") on the player.
- Monsters are unaffected by the mysterious force.
- Glowing monsters tend to emit more light.
- Monsters with "lord" and "king" in their names have dynamically created gender variants.
- Balrogs emit smoke, and carry a flaming lash.
- Piranhas devour corpses.

## Monster AI changes

All monsters in SpliceHack are smarter and make more effective use of items than their vanilla counterparts.

- SpliceHack implements an updated version of the intelligent pet patch, from [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"). This means that monsters will cast spells at one another, use ranged attacks against other monsters, and make more intelligent use of items.
- Monsters now use a wider variety of items, including (but not limited to) applying figurines, sacrificing corpses on altars, and playing instruments. They are even capable of making wishes from smoky potions.
- Monsters are capable of [riding](/wiki/Riding "Riding") other monsters. The movement speed of the rider is not changed based on the steed. This feature was later ported to [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack").
- Some monsters can call out to others of their kind, alerting them to the presence of the player.
- Monsters that eat corpses can gain [intrinsics](/wiki/Intrinsic "Intrinsic"), just like the player does.
- Monsters are capable of gaining [displacement](/wiki/Displacement "Displacement"), [jumping](/wiki/Jumping "Jumping"), [water walking](/wiki/Water_walking "Water walking"), and [teleportitis](/wiki/Teleportitis "Teleportitis").
- Monsters can be [stunned](/wiki/Stun "Stun") or turned [invisible](/wiki/Invisible "Invisible") by eating corpses.

## Gehennom changes

- Monsters do not leave corpses in Gehennom.
- Many domestic and mundane monsters are converted to their hellish counterparts in Gehennom. For example, kittens spawn as hellcats.

## Ascension run changes

The endgame of SpliceHack is designed to be more hectic than vanilla.

- While the player character has the Amulet of Yendor, many monsters are generated awake.
- Upon performing the invocation ritual, all [demon princes](/wiki/Demon_prince "Demon prince") and [demon lords](/wiki/Demon_lord "Demon lord") that have not yet been generated will spawn somewhere in the dungeon. This means that a player will almost definitely encounter [Demogorgon](/wiki/Demogorgon "Demogorgon") in the course of ascension.
- The [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") is populated by more player monsters than in vanilla. Due to the increased number of artifacts, it is more likely than in vanilla that you will encounter player monsters with artifact weapons.
- All [player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") are capable of stealing the Amulet from the player. If they succeed in stealing it, they will flee. Should a monster manage to make it to a coaligned high altar with the Amulet, they will sacrifice it, causing you to lose the game.

## Racial changes

- Dwarves start the game with booze, and their pickaxes are replaced with mattocks.
- Chaotic archeologists are considered valid, and begin the game with a pair of pistols.

## Shopkeepers

- Shopkeepers offer services, like in SLASH'EM.
- Shopkeepers may have better equipment.
